resources.string:
Please read this terms carefully before you start to take this quiz.
If you have further questions, please ask Google.

WHAT THIS QUIZ IS AND WHAT IT IS USED FOR
The name of this quiz is "This is not a quiz". This is quite self-explicative, but if it is not, all its questions are based on paradoxes. This may help to achieve a better knowledge of some of the many paradoxes out there, or maybe only damage your brain.

BEFORE YOU TAKE THIS QUIZ
Do not take this quiz, if you:
- are too smart
- are a robot

HOW TO TAKE THIS QUIZ
Select "I accept the terms" and "I am not a robot", then the "Continue to the quiz" button will start the quiz. There are five answers in total.

POSSIBLE SIDE EFFECTS
Like all quizzes, "This is not a quiz" can cause side effects, although not everybody gets them.

Stop taking this quiz, or go to accident and emergency if you notice any of the following symptoms.
Although the symptoms are very rare, they may be severe.
- Symptoms of an allergic reaction - sudden wheeziness, difficulty in breathing, chest pain, fever, sudden swellings of the face, lips, tongue, throat, hands or feet, rash or itching (especially affecting the whole body), pericarditis (inflammation of the membrane surrounding the heart), worsening of systemic lupus erythematosus (autoimmune disease)
- Increased pressure in the skull (severe headaches, blurred and/or double vision, blind spots, permanent loss of vision)
- Low blood pressure
- Unusual rapid heart beats (palpitations), fainting
- Blood disorders (symptoms may include tiredness, weakness, easy bruising or susceptibility to infection)
I do not accept the terms
Fine. You love paradoxes. Now select only one choice, please.
Please read the terms and select a choice.
Robots performing this quiz may incur into malfunctioning.
Don\'t think about it don\'t think about it…
Does the set of all those sets that do not contain themselves contain itself?
If this sentence is true, then Half Life 3 will be released.

A crocodile, who has stolen a child, promises her mother that her child will be returned if and only if she correctly predict what the crocodile will do next.\nIn which situations will a paradox arise for the crocodile?
The mother guesses that the child will be returned, the crocodile decides to return the child.
The mother guesses that the child will not be returned, the crocodile decides to keep the child.
The mother guesses that the child will be returned, the crocodile decides to keep the child.
The mother guesses that the child will not be returned, the crocodile decides to return the child.

Achilles is in a footrace with a tortoise. Achille allows the tortoise a head start of 100 meters. After some finite time, Achilles will have run 100 meters, bringing him to the tortoise\'s starting point. During this time, the tortoise has run a much shorter distance of 10 meters. But by the time Achilles has reached the 110 meters mark, the tortoise has walked another 5 meters. And by the time he has reached the 115 meters mark, the tortoise has walked another 2.5 meters, then 1.25 meters, and so on.\nWhen will Achilles catch up with the tortoise?
The right answer is marked in bold, while the answer given is marked with a color.
You are paradox-proof, like Wheatley.\nWait, did it sound like a compliment?
You are weak to paradox-based attacks, like GLaDOS.\nWait, did it sound like an offence?
